What you see in the photo is me, 8,000 km away from home, on one of the highest mountains in the world, smiling and happy that this wonâ€™t be my last night alive.

“Andrea, you wonâ€™t die on Annapurna, the diagnosis rules out appendicitis; you have a muscular issue near your abdomen.”
Reading through several NDEs (near-death experiences), people in those moments encounter visions of loved ones, a world without wars, or even a four-day workweekâ€”like reaching nirvana.
But my thoughts? Far less serene:
“My wallets, my passwords, my encrypted disks, my will written at 13â€¦my entire digital identity lost forever.”
ğŸ› ï¸ Birth of Casper This existential crisis led me to create Casperâ€”my digital alter ego designed to securely distribute my digital identity to my heirs (who donâ€™t even know they are heirs).
For security reasons, I wonâ€™t dive into the technical implementations but will discuss the challenges Casper must overcome to fulfill its role after I cease to exist.
ğŸ’€ Are You Alive? Casper must periodically verify if Iâ€™m still alive. Since no technology is infallible, it uses redundant and diverse strategies, including:
Robocalls, push notifications, SMS, email. Sensors (medical devices included). Key Considerations:
Redundancy: Signals must be sent repeatedly if thereâ€™s no response. Resilience: If Iâ€™m out climbing Nanga Parbat, Casper shouldnâ€™t assume Iâ€™m dead. Only after multiple attempts and checks does Casper declare me deceased and distribute my identity as planned.
ğŸŒ Redundancy Casper must be distributed globally to ensure resilience. This includes:
Multiple instances worldwide. At least one self-controlled instance (hardware included) to mitigate cloud-specific disasters. Complete redundancy requires planning for:
Power sources. Data lines. Hardware failures. ğŸ”’ Security Casper is a courier, not an inspector. It must:
Use end-to-end encryption. Rely on secure hardware for keys, such as YubiKey. âœ… Test, Test, Test Everything related to Casper should:
Be open source. Be stable and extensively tested. Undergo rigorous security checks using tools like SonarQube or Kiwan. ğŸ’£ Self-Destruct in 3â€¦2â€¦1 Casper must include a self-destruct mechanism to irreversibly erase data across all instances if tampering is suspected.
ğŸ› ï¸ Maintenance Casper isnâ€™t a “set it and forget it” project. It requires:
Periodic reviews, from the kernel level to user space. Continuous updates to adapt to technological evolution. ğŸ‘¼ğŸ¼ Was It Necessary? Absolutely NOT. ğŸ˜„
While there are safer ways to safeguard oneâ€™s digital legacy, Casper was a deeply personal project, driven by my fascination with solving seemingly insurmountable technological challenges.
Final Thoughts To this day, Casper ensures Iâ€™m aliveâ€”and hopefully, it has sparked your curiosity as much as it did mine. ğŸ™‚
